Your last sentence is the critically important one here. While austerians are working to serve the short term interests of a narrow economic elite, they are actually undermining the system that generates the wealth that such narrow elite is so obsessed with amassing. And they are doing so by creating an economic system that no longer benefits the rest of society.

History has proven time after time that free markets are the best generators of wealth and have pulled billions of people out of poverty. At the same time, a free market economic system can survive and thrive only when it is combined with governmental policies that ensure that the wealth that is generated improves society as a whole. In other words, the free market system must be tempered and supported by progressive policies that set the ground rules for the system, invest in the public sphere, provide a safety net, and support the rights of workers to organize for their interests.

The austerians have undermined the implicit bargain upon which free market economies throughout the world have thrived. In response to the Great Depression, we had the New Deal that saved capitalism from itself. Now, instead, austerians have taken advantage of the 2008 recession to impose policies that enriched a narrow set of banksters, while imposing harsh results on everyone else. The results won't be good for anyone in the long run.

Agreed that austerity has been a disastrous policy for the Eurozone & other European countries that have followed it, and the "respectable" European "leaders" are more foolish than the most comic politicians in insisting that the "answer" is MORE austerity.

However, all-out stimulus ALONE is also not the answer--at least not for all countries in Europe. Some (most?) need other economic & government structural reforms that vary from country to country but include, e.g., reducing tax evasion, reforming labor markets, stopping corruption, and probably more. Absent these added reforms the benefits of stimulus will likely be short-lived and not outweigh the cost of the extra debt .

So, instead of pressing on with austerity, the dominant Eurozone countries (especially Germany) should be putting together a stimulus fund for worse-off countries with conditions attached. To get a first stimulative infusion, the receiving countries would have to develop & legislatively pass a reform plan that addresses their structural problems. And later infusions would require progress in implementing those reforms.

I beg to differ. The five senses are inadequate to get a man on the moon. Math and science are essential. And where religious dogma reflects real dynamics of living forces, it will forever ring true and lead and enable us. A figurative construction of ancient scripture unveils the utility of its word.
"Religion" means: "to gather together". There is an essential core of viable guidance shared by all religions, and science can extrapolate from our limited senses to break new territory. A shared vision has consolidated our energies and focused on the tasks none could attempt alone.

@martin weiss,
My comment is admittedly out of context (it was supposed to be a reply to commenter "Thinkpoint," but got misdirected.), but I think the point is still valid. While imagination, solidarity and a spirit of discovery are essential ingredients in our human nature, these things do not benefit from adding a layer of religious metaphor. They are experienced by all people, whether religious or not.

The thing about religious dogma is that it doesn't ring true. Some people may have a feeling that there is a guiding consciousness in the void, but if feelings are to be admitted as evidence then my lack of feeling ought to have equal weight. In point of fact, religion has always been a drag on understanding at best and a dangerous enemy of science at worst. In the present day the teaching of evolution in classrooms is being challenged by creationists. Fundamentalist senators sit on science committees. Religious zealots in Texas are trying to rewrite history and science textbooks to eliminate inconvenient truths. We should focus our energies on freeing ourselves from this constricted, illogical worldview.

I also beg to differ, but about your claim that "only when penicillin was added did things improve."  While health took a serious downturn with the onset of agriculture, it began to improve far earlier than the 1940s.  It improved even before vaccination.  It improved in specific places like 17th and 18th century Europe because of its vast wealth as the result of conquering much of the planet.  People in Europe started to benefit from better housing, better water, and better sanitation, even though science at the time had not a clue that these might be useful.

By relying on the five senses, science has revealed a universe that would have been inconceivable to people who lived only a few generations ago. Since we can't investigate things that are beyond nature, it would seem pointless to include those things in any rational understanding of nature. In any event, our understanding hasn't appeared to suffer from the omission. For centuries, religion was our only recourse. People prayed to relieve suffering, or begged the almighty to spare a dying loved one. But only when penicillin was added to prayer did things improve.

Science has revealed mysteries, raised the ceiling, opened the windows, and turned ignorance and superstition into knowledge. Throughout history religious explanations of the world have given way to scientific explanations. I can't think of an instance where the reverse has been true.

The truth is that throughout their lost decade(s), Japan never jumped feet first into a sustained stimulus. One thing I don't understand about those of you who tout the importance of "confidence" is this: presumably, you believe in the free market (I say presumably because most conservatives believe in free enterprise for the poor and socialism for the rich)--so why don't you believe in the law of supply and demand?

A flat or dead economy needs demand. You don't get demand when spending is depressed. You need to spark it.

Please show me a graph illustrating the "law of confidence" in macroeconomics. I don't think you can--because it doesn't exist.

no, you cannot run above your capacity. that is how capacity is defined. and no an austere government runs below its capacity and puts many businesses out of business and loses the productivity so it can't boom.
Ever see a burst balloon blow up again when there's no human or any other source of air to fill it? Neither have the austerity mongers since they've run out of hot air.

.

The opposite of austerity is profligacy. A profligate government tends to run above its capacity for a long time, then it ultimately collapses. An austere government tends to run below its capacity for a long time, then it ultimately booms. Both the collapse and the boom take time.

You tell us (twice!) each week that profligacy is preferable to austerity because austere governments haven't boomed and profligate ones haven't collapsed.

I beg to differ. I view Japan, arguably the most profigate government on earth, as being in the midst of a multi-generational slow-moving collapse. And now that the West has caught this Japanese economic disease, we, too, are finding ourselves in the midst of a long slow road to disaster.

It will be painful for us to reverse course, but it can be done. It takes confidence, not fairy dust. Every pasing week adds to the challenge, and increases the cost.

". . . naturalistic philosophy declares that nothing beyond nature could have any conceivable relevance to what happens in nature. Yet there is not one shred of verifiable scientific evidence to support it."

Where is the verifiable scientific evidence supporting transcendence? That is the real problem for non-naturalists. Of course one can never disprove the existence of something beyond the material universe--but neither can one prove the existence of something beyond the material universe. We can find evidence for the material universe. We can speculate endlessly and fruitlessly on what might exist that we are incapable of perceiving. We're not going to get anywhere, or reach an agreement on anything about it.
